metadata.description: UK Industrial Strategy priority areas extracted from official documents

priorities.description: Development of safe, secure, and sustainable advanced air mobility aircraft including drones and electric vertical take-off and landing vehicles, with potential to contribute GBP 45 billion to the UK economy by 2030.
priorities.evidence_quote: The Government will support the development of safe, secure, and sustainable advanced air mobility aircraft, such as drones and electric vertical take-off and landing (eVTOLs) aircraft, through the Future of Flight programme, which will deliver the regulation, technologies, and infrastructure required for routine use.
funding_commitments: GBP 20 million+ for Future of Flight 2025-26
Six regulatory reforms agreed by Regulatory Innovation Office
source_documents: Advanced Manufacturing Sector Plan

priorities.description: Target to double annual business investment in Advanced Manufacturing sector from 21 billion to 39 billion GBP by 2035.
priorities.evidence_quote: Double annual business investment in the sector from GBP 21 billion to GBP 39 billion in 2035.
source_documents: Technical Annex to the UK Industrial Strategy

priorities.description: Seizing opportunities from growing demand across Clean Energy Industries to Digital and Technologies with 2,700 active UK companies.
priorities.evidence_quote: Advanced Materials – with the 2,700 active companies in the UK poised to seize opportunities created by growing demand from other sectors, from Clean Energy Industries to Digital and Technologies.
commitments: Support for National Composite Centre in Bristol
Support for Glass Futures in St Helens
Scaling up R&D in composites
source_documents: UK Industrial Strategy - Main Policy Paper (CP 1451)

priorities.description: Coordinated national approach to advanced materials including high-performance composites, advanced metal manufacturing, 2D materials, metamaterials, and carbon fibre to accelerate development and adoption across manufacturing sectors.
priorities.evidence_quote: To address fragmentation in the sector and accelerate pull through of materials from R&D to manufacturing, the Government has dedicated an initial GBP 50 million to deliver Phase 1 of a new, ambitious National Materials Innovation Programme (NMIP).
funding_commitments: GBP 50 million for NMIP Phase 1
GBP 42.5 million Defence Materials Centre of Excellence
GBP 395 million EPSRC investment in Henry Royce Institute to 2027
GBP 19.6 million for 3D Nanoscale Metamaterials Hub
source_documents: Advanced Manufacturing Sector Plan

priorities.description: Capitalising on UK expertise in jet engines, wings, and advanced systems for large commercial aircraft as the next generation of planes is developed.
priorities.evidence_quote: Aerospace – with our expertise in jet engines, wings, and advanced systems for large commercial aircraft putting the sector in a strong position to capitalise on demand as the next generation of planes is developed.
commitments: 10-year budget for Aerospace Technology Institute
Aerospace funding programmes available across UK
source_documents: UK Industrial Strategy - Main Policy Paper (CP 1451)

priorities.description: Pioneering new, more efficient aerospace technologies including next-generation narrow body aircraft, ultra-efficient engines (Rolls-Royce UltraFan), and sustainable aviation fuels, targeting 15% global market share by 2050.
priorities.evidence_quote: To ensure long-term R&D funding is matched with aircraft development cycles, Government will extend the Aerospace Technology Institute (ATI) Programme with up to GBP 2.3 billion to 2035, continuing to partner and share innovation risk with the businesses it supports.
funding_commitments: GBP 2.3 billion ATI Programme extension to 2035
GBP 35 billion private investment target to 2050
GBP 63 million Advanced Fuels Fund for 2025-26
source_documents: Advanced Manufacturing Sector Plan

priorities.description: Development and adoption of precision agriculture technologies including robotics, automation, advanced sensors, AI, and controlled environment systems to boost productivity, reduce emissions, and strengthen food security.
priorities.evidence_quote: Government will allocate at least GBP 200 million for the Farming Innovation Programme (FIP) to 2030, offering targeted funding to drive innovation in agriculture. This long-term investment will support increasing productivity in the sector, progress towards net zero and reduce the sector's reliance on seasonal migrant labour in horticulture.
funding_commitments: GBP 200 million+ Farming Innovation Programme to 2030
GBP 50 million private investment target by 2029
GBP 20 billion sector turnover target by 2035
Agri-Tech Export Accelerator Programme
source_documents: Advanced Manufacturing Sector Plan

priorities.description: Building domestic battery manufacturing capability across automotive, aerospace, maritime, defence, robotics, rail, and stationary energy storage to reduce dependency on global supply chains, particularly China.
priorities.evidence_quote: Through government investment of GBP 452 million to 2030, the Battery Innovation Programme will build on this, encouraging cross-sector innovation in emerging and next generation technologies through technology transfer funding that will connect academic researchers with UK industry and investor partnership funding.
funding_commitments: GBP 452 million for Battery Innovation Programme to 2030
GBP 12 million for battery materials scale-up via HVMC
GBP 680 million AESC Gigafactory finance (UKEF/NWF)
Agratas multibillion pound gigafactory project
source_documents: Advanced Manufacturing Sector Plan

priorities.priority_name: Connected and Automated Mobility (CAM) / Self-Driving Vehicles
priorities.description: Development and commercialization of self-driving vehicles, creating the first European market for self-driving vehicles and services through R&D, regulatory reform, and implementation of the Automated Vehicles Act 2024.
priorities.evidence_quote: This funding is underpinned by the world-leading Automated Vehicles Act 2024, which paves the way for self-driving vehicles to be used safely and securely on British roads by removing the need for a safety driver. Alongside full implementation of the act by 2027, the Government is also enabling commercial pilots by Spring 2026.
funding_commitments: GBP 150 million CAM Pathfinder programme extension to 2030
GBP 600 million+ in R&D funding for CAM
GBP 1.5 million for Formula Student AI
source_documents: Advanced Manufacturing Sector Plan

priorities.description: Leveraging UK innovation in propulsion, energy systems, and driverless technologies for the transition to Zero Emission Vehicles and Connected and Autonomous Mobility.
priorities.evidence_quote: Automotive, with our record of innovation in propulsion, energy systems, and driverless technologies giving the UK a competitive edge in the transition to Zero Emission Vehicles and Connected and Autonomous Mobility.
commitments: DRIVE35 programme with 10-year R&D funding commitment
Exploring pilot EV manufacturing cluster initiatives in North East and West Midlands
£400 million for charging infrastructure roll-out
Bringing Automated Vehicles Act fully into force
source_documents: UK Industrial Strategy - Main Policy Paper (CP 1451)

priorities.description: Continued investment in the HVMC network to help UK businesses develop and adopt engineering and manufacturing technology solutions, having already invested over GBP 1 billion in R&D facilities.
priorities.evidence_quote: HVMC helps UK businesses develop and adopt engineering and manufacturing technology solutions to transform their manufacturing processes, enhancing their productivity and profitability. Since its establishment, HVMC has invested more than GBP 1 billion in a nationwide network of R&D facilities and worked with more than 36,000 companies.
funding_commitments: GBP 1 billion+ HVMC investment in R&D facilities to date
Continued HVMC Technology Strategy support
source_documents: Advanced Manufacturing Sector Plan

priorities.priority_name: Industrial Digital Technologies and AI Adoption
priorities.description: Supporting SME adoption of industrial digital technologies including AI, digital twins, 3D printing, smart factories, and predictive maintenance through Made Smarter programmes.
priorities.evidence_quote: MSI delivers collaborative R&D projects and industry-focused research in the field of Industrial Digital Technologies (IDTs) - including AI, 3D printing, 'smart factories' and Robotics. Since 2020, this GBP 129 million programme has yielded GBP 202 million in private investment, and led to the development of over 350 industrial digital technology solutions for manufacturers.
funding_commitments: GBP 99 million Made Smarter Adoption expansion
GBP 29 million/year Made Smarter Innovation to 2030
GBP 12 million UK Data Sharing Infrastructure from April 2026
source_documents: Advanced Manufacturing Sector Plan

priorities.description: Accelerating uptake of robotics and automation across manufacturing through dedicated hubs and the Made Smarter programme.
priorities.evidence_quote: Accelerate the uptake of robotics and 'lean processes' through an expansion of our Made Smarter Adoption programme for SMEs and initial funding of £40 million for a new network for Robotics Adoption Hubs across the UK.
commitments: £40 million for Robotics Adoption Hubs network
Up to £99 million for Made Smarter Adoption programme expansion
Made Smarter scheme for Professional and Business Services
source_documents: UK Industrial Strategy - Main Policy Paper (CP 1451)

priorities.description: Accelerating adoption of robotics and automation technologies across manufacturing through a network of Robotics Adoption Hubs providing expertise, equipment, and connections for firms to adopt RAS technologies.
priorities.evidence_quote: To drive technology adoption, we are launching a new RAS programme, with an initial investment of GBP 40 million, which will create a new network of physical Robotics Adoption Hubs with the expertise, equipment, and connections to accelerate firms' take-up of robotics.
funding_commitments: GBP 40 million initial investment for Robotics Adoption Hubs
source_documents: Advanced Manufacturing Sector Plan

priorities.description: Strategic support for semiconductor and microelectronics innovation critical to electric vehicle production and advanced manufacturing supply chains.
priorities.evidence_quote: The Government will support electronics and machinery, providing strategic support for semiconductor and microelectronics innovation, including through UKRI and improved access to finance via the National Wealth Fund and British Business Bank.
funding_commitments: GBP 250 million Vishay semiconductor investment (Newport)
GBP 42 million UKRI Strength in Places Fund (Seagate photonics)
source_documents: Advanced Manufacturing Sector Plan

priorities.description: Securing advantages in areas critical to defence and growth through UK leadership as a spacefaring nation and international partnerships.
priorities.evidence_quote: Space – with our leadership as a spacefaring nation and our international partnerships helping the UK secure advantages in areas critical to defence and growth.
commitments: Space Industry Advisory Group partnership
source_documents: UK Industrial Strategy - Main Policy Paper (CP 1451)

priorities.description: Industrialization of space capabilities focusing on five priorities: Satellite Communications; Position, Navigation and Timing; In-orbit Servicing, Assembly and Manufacturing; Space Domain Awareness; and Space Data Architecture.
priorities.evidence_quote: To ensure the sector can progress from innovation through to industrialisation we will focus and increase funding on the 5 priorities in the Space Industrial Plan and Launch, including through a targeted funding package of up to GBP 80 million over five years.
funding_commitments: GBP 80 million targeted space funding over five years
GBP 135 million across NSIP, SCIF, and Unlocking Space programmes
GBP 75 million bilateral civil R&D funding over five years
GBP 7 million for regulatory sandboxes
source_documents: Advanced Manufacturing Sector Plan

priorities.priority_name: Zero Emission Vehicles (ZEV) and Electric Vehicle Manufacturing
priorities.description: Transition to zero-emission vehicle manufacturing with emphasis on cutting-edge propulsion technologies, power electronics, energy systems, and vehicle-to-grid technology. Target of over 1.3 million cars and commercial vehicles by 2035.
priorities.evidence_quote: The 'Driving Research and Investment in Vehicle Electrification' (DRIVE35) initiative will ensure the UK remains at the forefront of zero-emission vehicle manufacturing. This ambitious package of interventions will support the latest R&D in strategic vehicle technologies, accelerate their commercial scale-up, and unlock investment across all aspects of automotive electrification.
funding_commitments: GBP 2 billion automotive capital and R&D funding to 2030
GBP 500 million additional R&D support under DRIVE35
GBP 6.6 billion minimum private investment target
GBP 400 million charging infrastructure investment
GBP 1.4 billion for EV uptake support
source_documents: Advanced Manufacturing Sector Plan

priorities.description: Leveraging the UK's significant CO2 storage potential and transferable skills from oil and gas to become the CO2 storage hub of Europe.
priorities.evidence_quote: The Government announced up to £21.7 billion of available funding over 25 years to launch the UK's ambitious CCUS industry. We have reached financial close with East Coast Cluster and Liverpool Bay CCS, securing around £8 billion of private sector investment.
commitments: Up to £21.7 billion over 25 years for CCUS
£9.4 billion in capital budgets over Spending Review period
Support for Acorn CCUS project in Scotland
source_documents: UK Industrial Strategy - Main Policy Paper (CP 1451)

priorities.description: Critical infrastructure for decarbonising energy-intensive industries (cement, refining) and enabling net zero. UK has 78 billion tonnes CO2 storage capacity. Government committed up to GBP 21.7 billion over 25 years. East Coast Cluster and HyNet operational, Acorn and Viking clusters supported.
priorities.evidence_quote: The Government is providing increased backing to CCUS by allocating GBP 9.4bn in capital budgets over the Spending Review period. This will maximise deployment to fill the storage capacity of the East Coast Cluster and HyNet Cluster.
commitments: Up to GBP 21.7 billion over 25 years
GBP 9.4 billion capital budgets over Spending Review period
GBP 8 billion private sector investment secured for ECC and Liverpool Bay
Support announced for Acorn and Viking clusters
50% UK local content target from 2030 (industry-led)
Two CCUS clusters online by 2029
source_documents: Clean Energy Industries sector plan

priorities.description: Strategic priority to grow UK clean energy exports which have grown 158% since 2015. Global clean energy transition supply opportunity worth GBP 1 trillion to UK businesses to 2030. UKEF support with up to GBP 80 billion finance capacity.
priorities.evidence_quote: The UK's clean energy exports have grown by 158% since 2015. Our growing export industry serves diverse global markets, particularly the European Union and the United States. Supplying the goods and services to enable the global clean energy transition could be worth GBP 1 trillion to UK businesses to 2030.
commitments: GBP 80 billion UKEF finance capacity
GBP 10 billion clean growth finance target 2024-2029
GBP 13 billion UKEF direct lending available
New UKEF Critical Goods Guarantee product
Backing domestic SMRs for European deployment
New Trade Strategy published
source_documents: Clean Energy Industries sector plan

priorities.description: Target to at least double current investment levels in frontier Clean Energy Industries to over 30 billion GBP per year by 2035.
priorities.evidence_quote: At least a doubling of current investment levels across our frontier Clean Energy Industries to over GBP 30 billion per year by 2035.
source_documents: Technical Annex to the UK Industrial Strategy

priorities.description: Cross-cutting priority to build domestic manufacturing capacity and diversify supply chains across all frontier industries. GBP 1 billion Clean Energy Supply Chain Fund under Great British Energy. Focus on reducing import dependence and building UK content.
priorities.evidence_quote: Leveraging private investment into clean energy sectors via GBE, including to supply chains via a new GBP 1 billion Clean Energy Supply Chain fund aligned with the Clean Energy Industries Sector Plan. The Fund will offer support to companies who have significant potential to grow supply chains.
commitments: GBP 1 billion Clean Energy Supply Chain Fund
GBP 544 million Clean Industry Bonus allocated
50% UK content targets for CCUS and hydrogen from 2030
70% UK content target for Sizewell C
Circular Economy Roadmap for Clean Energy Industries by 2026
source_documents: Clean Energy Industries sector plan

priorities.description: Foundational infrastructure enabling clean power deployment and economic growth. Transformational grid expansion at scale not seen since 1960s. Domestic supply chain opportunities in transformers, switchgear, HVDC cables, and convertors. Could support 50,000-130,000 additional FTE jobs by 2050.
priorities.evidence_quote: Transforming the electricity network at a scale and pace not seen since the 1960s, so the grid can be an enabler not just for investment in clean power infrastructure but also across all sectors of the economy. This requires action to both build new grid capacity faster, investing strategically ahead of need.
commitments: Over GBP 60 billion proposed Transmission Owner investment 2026-2031
Connections Accelerator Service launching end of 2025
Industry Growth Plan development during 2025
Exploring Market Demand Guarantee for network equipment
Advanced Procurement Mechanism via Ofgem
GBP 10 billion per year investment in transmission networks to 2030
source_documents: Clean Energy Industries sector plan

priorities.description: Strategic sub-sector within offshore wind targeting deeper water deployments. Global market estimated at GBP 1 trillion by 2050. UK leveraging oil and gas sector expertise in floating substructures, fabrication, mooring and anchoring systems.
priorities.evidence_quote: The Floating Offshore Wind Taskforce estimates that the global market could be worth GBP 1 trillion by 2050. Key UK deployment zones in the North and Celtic Seas, alongside the UK's existing expertise in the fabrication of floating structures, also brings significant opportunities for the transition of skilled workers from carbon intensive sectors.
commitments: Reserved CIB funding for floating offshore wind supply chain
GBP 55 million for Port of Cromarty Firth
Up to GBP 80 million for Future Port Talbot project
Celtic Sea Leasing Round 5 for FLOW
source_documents: Clean Energy Industries sector plan

priorities.description: World-leading fusion energy programme capitalising on UKAEA capabilities. STEP programme at West Burton to deliver prototype fusion power plant by 2040. UK technological excellence in remote maintenance, HTS magnets, spherical tokamak design, tritium handling. Global private investment exceeds USD 7 billion.
priorities.evidence_quote: Delivering record investment in R&D for fusion energy, investing over GBP 2.5 billion over 5 years, including progressing the Spherical Tokamak for Energy Production (STEP) programme - supporting thousands of jobs. STEP will design and build a prototype fusion power station at the site of an old coal fired power plant in West Burton.
commitments: Over GBP 2.5 billion R&D investment over 5 years
STEP prototype fusion power plant by 2040
Fusion-specific National Policy Statement
UK Fusion Prospectus launch
Starmaker One - GBP 100 million fusion investment leveraged
source_documents: Clean Energy Industries sector plan

priorities.description: New publicly owned energy company to develop, invest in, build, and operate clean energy projects and supply chains. Over GBP 8.3 billion investment over Parliament including GBP 1 billion for supply chains. Critical enabler for clean energy deployment and manufacturing.
priorities.evidence_quote: Establishing Great British Energy (GBE) to develop, invest in, build and operate clean energy projects and supply chains across the UK. Great British Energy and Great British Energy - Nuclear (GBE-N) will invest more than GBP 8.3 billion over this Parliament in homegrown clean power.
commitments: Over GBP 8.3 billion investment over Parliament
GBP 1 billion Clean Energy Supply Chain Fund
GBP 200 million for local and community energy projects
GBP 300 million announced for offshore wind
GBP 700 million additional for IS-aligned sectors
source_documents: Clean Energy Industries sector plan

priorities.description: Emerging infrastructure sector for residual emissions in hard-to-abate sectors like aviation. National Infrastructure Commission notes GGRs could become major new infrastructure sector worth billions per year by 2050.
priorities.evidence_quote: Demand for Greenhouse Gas Removals (GGRs) will also rise rapidly, particularly as some sectors, such as aviation, are likely to retain some residual emissions. The National Infrastructure Commission (NIC) notes that GGRs could become 'a major new infrastructure sector for the UK worth billions per year by 2050'.
commitments: Consulting on bringing GGR technologies into UK Emissions Trading Scheme
Consultation on Non-Pipeline Transport for CO2 in 2025
source_documents: Clean Energy Industries sector plan

priorities.description: Domestic heating decarbonisation priority leveraging UK's position as largest European producer of residential gas boilers. Heat pump sales grew from 26,000 (2019) to 98,000 (2024). Potential GBP 4.8 billion GVA annually by 2050. Focus on manufacturing capacity, installer training, and demand stimulation.
source_documents: Clean Energy Industries sector plan
UK Industrial Strategy - Main Policy Paper (CP 1451)

priorities.description: Strategic role in clean energy transition for decarbonising hard-to-electrify industrial sectors and heavy transport. Export potential of GBP 5.8-9.8 billion by 2050. First regional hydrogen network from 2031. UK strengths in electrolysis technologies and cavern storage capacity.
source_documents: Clean Energy Industries sector plan
UK Industrial Strategy - Main Policy Paper (CP 1451)

priorities.description: Development of hydrogen propulsion technologies across all transport modes through the Hydrogen Propulsion Manufacturing Taskforce to attract and maximize UK investment.
priorities.evidence_quote: The Hydrogen Propulsion Manufacturing Taskforce comprised of senior industry leaders which will help set out an ambitious industrial policy for the UK manufacturing of hydrogen propulsion technologies across all transport modes, attracting and maximising investment opportunities in UK-made hydrogen systems.
funding_commitments: Revised Hydrogen Strategy 2025
ZeroAvia hydrogen-electric powertrain manufacturing facility
source_documents: Advanced Manufacturing Sector Plan

priorities.priority_name: National Wealth Fund Clean Energy Investment
priorities.description: Government's principal investor with GBP 27.8 billion capital to catalyse private investment in clean energy projects. At least GBP 5.8 billion committed to carbon capture, hydrogen, gigafactories, ports, and green steel over Parliament.
priorities.evidence_quote: Empowering the National Wealth Fund (NWF) with a total GBP 27.8 billion in capital, to enable it to take on higher-risk investments, including equity. It will invest in capital intensive projects, businesses, and assets, with at least GBP 5.8 billion targeting carbon capture, low carbon hydrogen, gigafactories, ports and green steel over this Parliament.
commitments: GBP 27.8 billion total capital
At least GBP 5.8 billion for priority clean energy sectors
Strategic Partnerships for regional delivery
Concessional finance approaches
source_documents: Clean Energy Industries sector plan

priorities.description: Re-asserting and revolutionising the UK's role as a leading, responsible and innovative nuclear nation across both civil and defence capabilities.
priorities.evidence_quote: We are investing £14.2 billion to build Sizewell C, which will be a jobs and growth engine, supporting 10,000 jobs at peak construction and working with 3,500 suppliers in all parts of the UK. We are also investing over £2.5 billion to enable one of Europe's first Small Modular Reactor (SMR) programmes.
commitments: £14.2 billion for Sizewell C
Over £2.5 billion for Small Modular Reactors
£2.5 billion investment in fusion over five years
£20 billion over four years into civil nuclear
Over £100 billion projected through UK defence nuclear suppliers over 10 years
Supporting 120,000 jobs in nuclear sector by early 2030s
source_documents: UK Industrial Strategy - Main Policy Paper (CP 1451)

priorities.description: Revival of civil nuclear sector with largest investment in over 50 years. Focus on large-scale projects (Hinkley Point C, Sizewell C) and emerging Small Modular Reactor (SMR) and Advanced Modular Reactor (AMR) technologies. Civil and defence nuclear workforce estimated to need 120,000 employees by early 2030s.
priorities.evidence_quote: Providing significant investment in the nuclear sector, with GBP 14.2 billion for Sizewell C, the first state-funded nuclear power station since Sizewell B began construction in 1988. Sizewell C will support around 10,000 jobs at peak construction and thousands more nationwide.
commitments: GBP 14.2 billion for Sizewell C
Over GBP 2.5 billion for SMR programme
Rolls-Royce SMR selected as preferred bidder
GBP 300 million for HALEU fuel programme
70% UK content target for Sizewell C
New National Policy Statement EN-7 for nuclear
source_documents: Clean Energy Industries sector plan

priorities.description: World-leading offshore wind deployment with target of 43-50 GW by 2030, including fixed-bottom and floating offshore wind technologies. Focus on domestic manufacturing, supply chain development, and export growth. Industry estimates sector contributes around GBP 2-3 billion GVA per GW installed.
source_documents: Clean Energy Industries sector plan
UK Industrial Strategy - Main Policy Paper (CP 1451)

priorities.description: Revival of onshore wind following removal of de facto ban in July 2024. Target deployment of 27-29 GW by 2030. Focus on balance of plant, operations, and workforce development with potential to support up to 45,000 jobs by 2030.
priorities.evidence_quote: Publishing our Onshore Wind Strategy, the first time the Government has published a strategy specifically for onshore wind. The Strategy will set out over 40 actions to unlock onshore wind deployment, tackling key barriers such as planning, aviation and defence. Government is committed to deploying 27-29GW of onshore wind by 2030 in GB.
commitments: 27-29 GW onshore wind by 2030
First dedicated Onshore Wind Strategy
Reintroduction into NSIP regime
Industry-led local content goal by end of 2025
Considering expansion of Clean Industry Bonus to onshore wind
source_documents: Clean Energy Industries sector plan

priorities.description: Port infrastructure explicitly identified as a key foundational input specifically for Clean Energy Industries growth.
priorities.evidence_quote: Port infrastructure is key to the growth of Clean Energy Industries.
source_documents: Technical Annex to the UK Industrial Strategy

priorities.description: Foundational infrastructure for offshore wind and clean energy deployment. National Wealth Fund committed at least GBP 5.8 billion to priority sectors including ports. Strategic investments in Port of Cromarty Firth and Future Port Talbot.
priorities.evidence_quote: Mobilising investment into ports, a foundational industry for Clean Energy Industries, by working across government and Public Financial Institutions to develop bespoke solutions, including through innovative use of financing. As part of this, ports are one of the five sectors which the National Wealth Fund has committed at least GBP 5.8 billion of its capital to.
commitments: GBP 55 million awarded to Port of Cromarty Firth
Up to GBP 80 million for Future Port Talbot project
NWF priority sector commitment
source_documents: Clean Energy Industries sector plan

priorities.description: Digital technologies enabling efficient decarbonised energy system. Domestic market for smart systems and flexibility solutions could contribute GBP 1.3 billion by 2050, with GBP 2.7 billion in exports. Includes smart charging, energy storage, and data sharing.
priorities.evidence_quote: By 2050, the domestic market for smart systems and flexibility solutions, including EV smart chargers and smart network equipment, could contribute almost GBP 1.3 billion to the nation's economy, with exports adding a further GBP 2.7 billion.
commitments: Clean Flexibility Roadmap to be published
Energy smart data scheme exploration
Automatic Asset Registration programme
source_documents: Clean Energy Industries sector plan

priorities.description: Building UK SAF production capability through the SAF Mandate, Advanced Fuels Fund, and revenue certainty mechanism, with potential to support 15,000 UK jobs and GBP 5 billion GVA by 2050.
priorities.evidence_quote: The use of Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF) presents a growth opportunity for the UK through their critical role in decarbonising aviation. In 2050, up to 15,000 UK jobs and GBP 5 billion GVA could be supported with future low-carbon fuel production, including SAF.
funding_commitments: GBP 63 million Advanced Fuels Fund 2025-26
SAF Mandate launched January 2025
Revenue certainty mechanism for SAF investment
source_documents: Advanced Manufacturing Sector Plan

priorities.description: Maintain UK's position as the most digitally mature advertising market in Western Europe, with GBP 109 billion indirect GVA contribution. Internet advertising expected to reach GBP 44 billion by 2028.
priorities.evidence_quote: Support adtech businesses with accelerator programs, to upskill founders towards international expansion and connect them with key investors... UK will build on its position as the second largest exporter of advertising and marketing services.
concrete_commitments: Adtech accelerator programmes for international expansion
Online Advertising Taskforce to extend industry best practice
Expanded GREAT campaign for UK advertising and AdTech
Procurement reforms to help SME advertising agencies access public sector contracts
source_documents: Creative Industries Sector Plan

priorities.description: Establish the UK as a global leader in the emerging 'createch' sector by combining creative innovation with cutting-edge technology (robotics, engineering biology, XR, AI) to generate novel products, services and experiences. Expected to generate GBP 18 billion GVA and 160,000 jobs over the next decade.
priorities.evidence_quote: We will establish the UK as a global leader in the emerging 'createch' sector... Createch businesses have the same growth potential as other technology firms and are expected to generate GBP 18 billion in gross value added (GVA) and 160,000 jobs over the next decade.
concrete_commitments: GBP 100 million UKRI investment over the Spending Review for R&D creative clusters
GBP 25 million Creative Futures programme for five new CoSTAR R&D labs and two showcase spaces
UKRI to publish new Creative Industries R&D strategy in 2025
Revised HMRC guidance for R&D tax reliefs to clarify eligibility of creative sector projects
source_documents: Creative Industries Sector Plan

priorities.description: Unlock potential of 55 major clusters and 709 microclusters across the UK, reducing concentration in London and South East (currently 67% of Creative Industries GVA). Support 12 identified high-potential creative clusters.
priorities.evidence_quote: The government has identified 12 creative clusters across the UK where we will work with local leaders and devolved governments to drive growth... A new GBP 150 million Creative Places Growth Fund devolved to six Mayoral Strategic Authorities.
concrete_commitments: GBP 150 million Creative Places Growth Fund for six Mayoral Strategic Authorities
GBP 100 million UKRI investment for next wave of R&D creative clusters
Support for creative corridors (Northern city regions, West of England-South Wales, Thames Estuary)
GBP 10 million London Mayor investment over four years
New Creative Places Group for policy coordination
Local Innovation Partnerships Fund up to GBP 500 million
source_documents: Creative Industries Sector Plan

priorities.description: Establish a trusted marketplace for selling, buying, licensing, and enabling permitted access to digitised cultural and creative assets while protecting copyright and enabling AI development. Make UK IP rights the best protected in the world.
priorities.evidence_quote: We will establish a Creative Content Exchange (CCE) to be a trusted marketplace for selling, buying, licensing, and enabling permitted access to digitised cultural and creative assets... concrete_commitments: Creative Content Exchange marketplace development
Copyright and AI framework consultation with economic impact assessment
Expert working groups on transparency, licensing and technical standards
UK+ exhaustion of IP rights regime maintained

priorities.description: Establishing a Creative Content Exchange as a trusted marketplace for digitised cultural and creative assets.
priorities.evidence_quote: Establish a Creative Content Exchange (CCE) to be a trusted marketplace for selling, buying, licensing, and enabling permitted access to digitised cultural and creative assets. This new marketplace will open up new revenue streams and allow content owners to commercialise and financialise their assets.
commitments: Creative Content Exchange establishment
£100 million UKRI support for creative businesses over Spending Review
£25 million Creative Futures programme
Five new CoSTAR R&D labs

priorities.evidence_quote: Increase annual business investment by the Creative Industries from GBP 17 billion to GBP 31 billion by 2035.
source_documents: Technical Annex to the UK Industrial Strategy

priorities.description: Build a resilient, skilled and diverse workforce fit for the future by reforming skills provision, supporting creative education, and addressing skills gaps and shortages affecting 7% of businesses with shortage vacancies and 11% experiencing skills gaps.
priorities.evidence_quote: We will unlock growth by reforming the skills system to address skills gaps and shortages in growth-driving sectors... Working with industry, DfE and Skills England we will refine and develop the growth and skills offer to deliver apprenticeships and skills training.
concrete_commitments: GBP 9 million refreshed UK-wide creative careers service
National Centre for Arts and Music Education launching September 2026
GBP 132.5 million for disadvantaged young people's enrichment opportunities
Creative freelance champion to be appointed in 2025
Short courses in digital, AI and engineering funded through Growth and Skills Levy from April 2026
Creative Higher Technical Qualifications (HTQs) for animation and audio-visual production in September 2025
Skills passports implementation beginning 2026

priorities.description: Strengthen UK's position as third largest creative services exporter globally, with Creative Industries accounting for 15% of all UK services exports. Diversify beyond traditional EU and US markets to fast-growing Asia-Pacific, GCC and emerging markets.
priorities.evidence_quote: UK Export Finance (UKEF) has GBP 80 billion in financing capacity to support UK exporters, across the IS-8 including the Creative Industries.
concrete_commitments: GBP 80 billion UK Export Finance capacity available
Reformed Creative Industries Trade and Investment Board with new globally recognised Chair
New trade and investment plans for priority and high-growth markets
Increased creative trade missions including to Asia-Pacific
GREAT Trade and Investment campaign including Greater Together Los Angeles 2026 and Expo 2030 Saudi Arabia
UK-EU Summit commitments on touring artists and cultural exchange
Investment in British Fashion Council NEWGEN programme
Support for BFI Film Festival, London Games Festival, World Design Congress 2025

priorities.description: Maintain UK's position as a global centre for screen production, with GBP 4.8 billion of inward investment in 2024. Support mixed film and TV ecology including independent producers, public service broadcasters, and inward investment.

source_documents: Defence Industrial Strategy: Making Defence an Engine for Growth

source_documents: digital_tech

priorities.description: Maintaining and enhancing UK leadership in sustainable finance, ranked first globally for eight consecutive years. Includes UK Sustainability Reporting Standards, transition finance market development, ESG ratings provider regulation, and supporting voluntary carbon and nature markets.
priorities.evidence_quote: The UK is the leading centre for sustainable finance, ranked first in the world for an eighth consecutive time in the Global Green Finance Index. There is increasing demand for sustainable finance products globally, and this represents an opportunity to build on the UK's existing leadership.
source_documents: Financial Services Growth and Competitiveness Strategy

priorities.description: Transforming UK wholesale markets through the Wholesale Financial Markets Digital Strategy (WFMDS), adopting blockchain/DLT and AI technologies, removing paper share certificates, appointing a Digital Markets Champion, and facilitating innovation in financial market infrastructure.
priorities.evidence_quote: Publishing a Wholesale Financial Markets Digital Strategy (WFMDS), which sets a vision for digitalising UK wholesale markets. Through the WFMDS, the government, working with industry, will use technology to optimise and transform our markets.
source_documents: Financial Services Growth and Competitiveness Strategy

priorities.description: British Business Bank to commit additional 4 billion GBP Industrial Strategy Growth Capital, crowding in 12 billion GBP private capital, with direct investments up to 60 million GBP for strategically important companies, targeting UK as leading European Life Sciences finance hub by 2030.
priorities.evidence_quote: The Life Sciences sector will benefit as the BBB commits an additional 4 billion of Industrial Strategy Growth Capital to support investment and growth in the Government's Industrial Strategy growth-driving sectors (IS-8), crowding in 12 billion of private sector capital. This will include the Bank doubling its investment in new fund managers, cornerstone funds, and building the capacity to make direct investments of up to 60 million in strategically important companies.
source_documents: Life Sciences Sector Plan

priorities.description: Leverage the BioNTech strategic partnership and Cancer Vaccine Launch Pad to provide personalised cancer therapies for up to 10,000 UK patients by 2030, accelerating cancer vaccine trials and positioning UK as global leader in cancer innovation.
priorities.evidence_quote: In 2023, the Government and BioNTech - the pioneering company behind mRNA vaccines used to tackle COVID-19 - entered into a strategic partnership, which aims to provide personalised cancer therapies for up to 10,000 UK patients by 2030... BioNTech intends to set up two R&D hubs - the first one in Cambridge focused on genomics, oncology, structural biology, and regenerative medicine.
source_documents: Life Sciences Sector Plan

priorities.description: Slash commercial interventional clinical trial set-up times to under 150 days through O'Shaughnessy reforms, NIHR governance updates, and a dual health and growth mandate, aiming to double commercial trial participants by 2026 and again by 2029.
priorities.evidence_quote: Slashing trial set up times to under 150 days: By implementing the O'Shaughnessy reforms, updating the NIHR governance and placing a dual health and growth mandate on the NIHR, we will cut delays that deter investors and aim to double commercial interventional trial participants by 2026, and again by 2029.
source_documents: Life Sciences Sector Plan

priorities.description: Comprehensive genomics investment including Genomics England (over 650 million GBP for 500,000+ genomes), Our Future Health (up to 354 million GBP for 5 million participants), UK Biobank expansion, and NHS Genomic Medicine Service with potential for genomics to contribute to half of all healthcare interventions by 2035.
priorities.evidence_quote: By 2030, Genomics England, supported by over 650 million of government funding, will host one of the largest genomic research databases globally with over 500,000 genomes... Our Future Health will become the largest longitudinal health research cohort and clinical trials resource in the world, with up to five million consented participants.
source_documents: Life Sciences Sector Plan

priorities.description: Up to 600 million GBP investment to create the world's most advanced, secure, and AI-ready health data platform, uniting genomic, diagnostic, and clinical data at population scale to attract global trials and AI investment.
priorities.evidence_quote: Up to 600 million investment from Government alongside the Wellcome Trust, to create the world's most advanced, secure, and AI-ready health data platform. It will unite genomic, diagnostic, and clinical data at population scale, turning NHS and wider healthcare data into a magnet for global trials and AI investment.
source_documents: Life Sciences Sector Plan

priorities.description: Creating the world's most advanced, secure, and AI-ready health data platform to attract global trials and AI investment.
priorities.evidence_quote: Realising a Health Data Research Service with up to £600 million investment from Government, alongside the Wellcome Trust to create the world's most advanced, secure and AI-ready health data platform.
commitments: Up to £600 million for Health Data Research Service (with Wellcome Trust)
More than £650 million over 5 years for Genomics England
Up to £354 million for Our Future Health
Up to £20 million for UK BioBank
At least £30 million for preclinical infrastructure
Slashing trial set up time to under 150 days
source_documents: UK Industrial Strategy - Main Policy Paper (CP 1451)

priorities.description: Build and deploy a patient-accessible HealthStore for approved health apps to manage or treat conditions including dermatology, physiotherapy, and mental health cognitive behaviour therapy, funded centrally with nationwide rollout.
priorities.evidence_quote: For patients, we will build, test and iterate a 'HealthStore', which will enable access to approved health apps to manage or treat their condition. Areas with digital tools that show significant promise include dermatology, physiotherapy, and cognitive behaviour therapy for mental health conditions. The products will be funded from the centre and nationwide rollout will be piloted once the HealthStore is established.
source_documents: Life Sciences Sector Plan

priorities.description: Deliver ambitious Healthcare Goals across five disease areas (Addiction, Cancer, Dementia, Mental Health, Obesity) with significant government funding, ministerially-appointed international expert chairs, and bespoke initiatives supporting R&D, adoption, and inward investment.
priorities.evidence_quote: Deliver the ambitions of the Government's Healthcare Goals programme across Addiction, Cancer, Dementia, Mental Health, and Obesity, with continued significant government funding. Each Healthcare Goals programme is led by ministerially-appointed international experts operating as Chair(s).
source_documents: Life Sciences Sector Plan

priorities.description: Champion strong international regulatory harmonisation through Mutual Recognition Agreements, Ricardo Fund supporting UK regulators internationally, WTO pharmaceutical agreements, and participation in European Critical Medicines Alliance.
priorities.evidence_quote: Using all our international dialogues, partnerships, and agreements, we will champion strong international regulatory cooperation and harmonisation. We will use all levers, including our Mutual Recognition Agreements and bilateral engagement between regulators. The latter will be supported by the newly announced Ricardo Fund.
source_documents: Life Sciences Sector Plan

priorities.description: Up to 520 million GBP to bring globally mobile manufacturing investments to the UK, building sovereign capability across pharmaceuticals and MedTech, creating high-value jobs, and strengthening domestic health resilience and supply chain security.
priorities.evidence_quote: Backing manufacturing with up to 520 million: The Life Sciences Innovative Manufacturing Fund (LSIMF) will bring globally mobile manufacturing investments to the UK. This will help build and maintain the UK's critical sovereign capability across the sector, creating high-value jobs nationwide, and strengthen domestic health resilience and supply chain security.
source_documents: Life Sciences Sector Plan

priorities.description: Bringing globally mobile manufacturing investments to the UK to build critical sovereign capability and create high-value jobs.
priorities.evidence_quote: Backing manufacturing with up to £520 million through the Life Sciences Innovative Manufacturing Fund, which will bring globally mobile manufacturing investments to the UK.
commitments: Up to £520 million Life Sciences Innovative Manufacturing Fund
Over £2 billion government funding for Life Sciences over Spending Review
Bespoke approach for investments over £250 million
Low-friction Procurement pathway for MedTech
source_documents: UK Industrial Strategy - Main Policy Paper (CP 1451)

priorities.priority_name: Life Sciences R&D and Investment Leadership
priorities.description: Multiple targets including leading European commercial R&D investment by 2030 (global excluding US/China by 2035), leading European scale-up finance by 2030, top three fastest patient access in Europe by 2030, and leading European FDI by 2030.
priorities.evidence_quote: The UK will have more investment in commercial R&D than any other European economy by 2030, and more than any other country globally (excluding the US and China) by 2035.
source_documents: Technical Annex to the UK Industrial Strategy

priorities.priority_name: Life Sciences Skills and Workforce Development
priorities.description: Build a diverse, highly skilled Life Sciences workforce through Skills England coordination, Turing AI Pioneer Fellowships, CERSI regulatory science programme, and Global Talent Taskforce for international recruitment.
priorities.evidence_quote: Build a training and skills system that delivers a diverse and highly skilled Life Sciences workforce. Skills England will work with Life Sciences employers and gain insight from devolved governments to understand the skills needs of the sector... New Turing AI Pioneer Fellowships will improve AI skills across multiple scientific and research domains, including Life Sciences.
source_documents: Life Sciences Sector Plan

priorities.description: Strengthen Life Sciences supply chain security through new Supply Chain Centre identifying strategic vulnerabilities, supporting UK manufacturing capability, diversifying critical inputs, and embedding economic security in LSIMF and National Wealth Fund programmes.
priorities.evidence_quote: The Life Sciences sector depends on complex global supply chains, often reliant on a small number of international suppliers for critical components... Through our new Supply Chain Centre, we will identify strategic vulnerabilities and take targeted steps to build resilience - whether by supporting UK manufacturing capability, diversifying sources of key inputs, or improving access to resilience finance.
source_documents: Life Sciences Sector Plan

priorities.description: Streamline NHS procurement through a Rules Based Pathway (RBP) for MedTech from April 2026, an NHS Innovator Passport, and Value Based Procurement to enable innovative products to reach patients more quickly with less bureaucracy.
priorities.evidence_quote: Introducing low-friction procurement: Streamlining the route to procurement, ensuring it is clearer and less bureaucratic, giving industry low-friction access to the NHS through a Rules Based Pathway (RBP) for MedTech and an NHS 'Innovator Passport', enabling innovative MedTech products to reach patients more quickly.
source_documents: Life Sciences Sector Plan

priorities.description: Support the UK MedTech industry (154,000 employees, 34 billion GBP turnover, 6% annual growth) encompassing medical devices, diagnostics, and digital technologies, addressing regulatory and procurement challenges causing 33% of firms to remove products from UK market.
priorities.evidence_quote: The UK's MedTech frontier industry employed around 154,000 staff and generated 34 billion in turnover in 2021/22. The frontier industry encompasses medical devices, diagnostics (both in vivo and in vitro), and digital technologies... in 2024, 33% of MedTech firms reported removing products from the UK market due to a combination of regulatory and procurement barriers.
source_documents: Life Sciences Sector Plan

priorities.description: Align Life Sciences sector with NHS transformation goals: shift from hospital to community (diagnostics and digital tools), analogue to digital (AI and data), and sickness to prevention (genomics, early detection, personalised medicine).
priorities.evidence_quote: We will do so in a way that supports our National Health Service (NHS), not strains it - by embracing the three major health shifts this Government is determined to deliver: From hospital to community... From analogue to digital... From sickness to prevention.
source_documents: Life Sciences Sector Plan

priorities.description: New NIHR R&D Innovation Catalyst to pull through innovations from UKRI and other routes, providing R&D funding through translational phases with milestone-based progression and wraparound support connecting innovators to testbeds, VCs, regulators, and procurement.
priorities.evidence_quote: Substantially enhance the NIHR offer to BioTech and MedTech SMEs to develop and evaluate high value innovation. Delivered through the introduction of a new NIHR R&D Innovation Catalyst, pulling through innovations developed by UKRI and other routes, and meeting the demands of the health and care system.
source_documents: Life Sciences Sector Plan

priorities.description: Connect Life Sciences clusters across the Oxford to Cambridge Growth Corridor with flagship infrastructure investments including East-West Rail to address chronic lab space shortages and build globally competitive Life Sciences ecosystem.
source_documents: Life Sciences Sector Plan
Technical Annex to the UK Industrial Strategy

priorities.description: Support the UK pharmaceutical industry (150,000 employees, 74 billion GBP turnover, 17% of total UK business R&D) spanning large UK firms like AstraZeneca and GSK, multinationals, and SMEs across branded, generic, and biosimilar medicines.
priorities.evidence_quote: The UK's pharmaceuticals frontier industry employed around 150,000 staff and generated 74 billion in turnover in 2021/22... Expenditure on pharmaceutical R&D totalled 9 billion in 2023, the largest contribution (17%) to total business R&D in the same year.
source_documents: Life Sciences Sector Plan

priorities.description: Establish pre-clinical translational hub and up to three fully integrated translational networks backed by at least 30 million GBP, developing alternatives to animal models and accelerating development of new medicines and medical technologies.
priorities.evidence_quote: The Government will establish pre-clinical translational infrastructure to drive development of pre-clinical models as an alternative to animals, and will develop up to three fully integrated translational networks in key areas of health research... This infrastructure will be backed by at least 30 million of government funding.
source_documents: Life Sciences Sector Plan

priorities.priority_name: Prevention and Multiple Long-Term Conditions Research
priorities.description: Shift government health R&D investment to prioritize primary and secondary prevention and Multiple Long-Term Conditions (MLTCs), making the UK a global leader in preventative healthcare products and services.
priorities.evidence_quote: The Government will shift investment in health R&D with a focus on primary and secondary prevention and Multiple Long-Term Conditions (MLTCs). The Government's goal is to mobilise public and private investment into prevention that improves our health and prosperity, and to make this country a global leader in preventative healthcare products and services.
source_documents: Life Sciences Sector Plan

priorities.description: Establish devolutionary Regional Health Innovation Zones to experiment with new commissioning models, redesign patient pathways, and simplify procurement, initially 2-3 trailblazer regions with ambition to scale nationally.
priorities.evidence_quote: Establish Regional Health Innovation 'Zones' for large scale development and implementation of innovation, for scale-up across the health and care system... Empowered by devolutionary freedoms, the Zones will bring together existing entities - including Integrated Care Boards (ICBs), providers, mayors, and industry - to experiment, test, and generate evidence for complex interventions.
source_documents: Life Sciences Sector Plan

priorities.priority_name: Regulatory Reform and Streamlined Market Access
priorities.description: Supporting MHRA to become a faster, more agile regulator with international reliance pathways for medicines and medical devices, coordinated with NICE for parallel approvals, enabling patients to access cutting-edge innovation 3-6 months faster.
priorities.evidence_quote: Streamlining regulation and market access: Supporting the Medicines and Healthcare products Regulatory Agency (MHRA) to become a faster, more agile regulator, and giving industry a clearer route to market through joint advice and parallel approvals with the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE), alongside a route for international reliance for medicines and medical devices so patients benefit sooner from cutting-edge innovation.
source_documents: Life Sciences Sector Plan

priorities.description: Secure at least one major strategic partnership annually with leading Life Sciences companies and establish dedicated support service for 10-20 high-potential UK companies to scale, attract investment, and remain headquartered in the UK.
priorities.evidence_quote: Partnering with industry to drive growth and innovation: Building on our collaborative approach with the sector, we will continue to partner with industry throughout delivery, and working directly with individual companies, we will secure at least one major strategic partnership annually with leading Life Sciences companies. Additionally, a dedicated support service will be established to help 10-20 high-potential UK companies to scale, attract investment, and remain headquartered in the UK.
source_documents: Life Sciences Sector Plan

priorities.priority_name: TechBio and AI in Life Sciences
priorities.description: Position UK as global leader in AI-driven Life Sciences through AI Opportunities Action Plan, Sovereign AI Unit, Dawn supercomputer for health, support for TechBio companies fusing biotechnology with data science, and MHRA AI regulatory framework.
priorities.evidence_quote: The Government is committed to making the UK a global leader in AI-driven Life Sciences through the AI Opportunities Action Plan and the aligned Digital and Technologies Sector Plan... One of the most dynamic areas of growth is TechBio, which fuses biotechnology with data science. TechBio companies are pioneering AI-driven applications in drug discovery.
source_documents: Life Sciences Sector Plan

priorities.description: Develop the emerging field of AI Assurance Technology as a major growth engine for UK PBS. As AI becomes integral to operations, firms require robust mechanisms to validate, monitor, and certify AI systems ensuring regulatory compliance and ethical standards. The UK AI assurance market could grow from around 1 billion GBP to 6.5 billion GBP by 2035.
priorities.evidence_quote: The emerging field of AI Assurance Technology (AIAT) has the potential to be a major growth engine for the UK's PBS sector. As AI becomes integral to operations, firms require robust mechanisms to validate, monitor, and certify AI systems... The UK's AI assurance market could grow from around 1 billion in GVA to as high as 6.5 billion by 2035.
source_documents: Professional and Business Services sector plan

priorities.priority_name: AI and Digital Technology Adoption in PBS
priorities.description: Position the UK PBS sector as the foremost adopter and most trusted deployer of AI globally. This includes launching a Made Smarter-style technology adoption programme for PBS SMEs, expanding Innovate UK's Next Generation Professional and Financial Services programme, and appointing a PBS AI Champion. The government has committed over 150 million GBP to fund five transformative programmes for PBS innovation and technology adoption.
priorities.evidence_quote: We have a leadership opportunity for the UK to position PBS as the foremost adopter and most trusted deployer of AI in the world. We have done well so far, with AI adoption already relatively high in the sector (at 38% of businesses, 13 percentage points higher than the average across the economy).
source_documents: Professional and Business Services sector plan

priorities.description: Enable transition to broader provision of business advice including real-time management reporting and ESG/climate transition reporting. Reform audit and corporate governance through FRC transformation, develop UK Sustainability Reporting Standards (UK SRS), and facilitate proportionate regulation to support sector growth.
priorities.evidence_quote: The Accountancy, Audit, and Tax sector contributed 33.3 billion to the UK GVA in 2024... Enable Accountancy, Audit, and Tax companies to transition to the broader provision of business advice, incorporating real time management reporting and new service lines, such as ESG and climate transition reporting.
source_documents: Professional and Business Services sector plan

priorities.description: Strengthen cybersecurity across PBS firms through promotion of Cyber Essentials scheme, support from Cyber Resilience Centres, and partnership with National Cyber Security Centre. Address the critical need for PBS businesses to protect confidential client information.
priorities.evidence_quote: PBS businesses capture and retain confidential business and client information. Cyber Essentials is a government scheme that helps businesses to assure themselves, their customers, and investors, that they have the right basic cyber security controls in place.
source_documents: Professional and Business Services sector plan

priorities.description: Invest up to 12 million GBP in UK Data Sharing Infrastructure Initiatives from April 2026, learning from international practices including Common European Data Spaces. Promote effective governance, legal frameworks, data interoperability, security, and trust for cross-sector data sharing.
priorities.evidence_quote: Invest up to 12m in UK Data Sharing Infrastructure Initiatives from April 2026. Learning from international practices, including the Common European Data Spaces, these will promote effective and more coordinated approaches to governance, legal considerations, regulations, data interoperability, security, and trust.
source_documents: Professional and Business Services sector plan

priorities.description: Strengthen the UK's position as world leader in Legal Services through accelerated AI and digital adoption, continued funding for LawtechUK programme, maintaining the strength of English and Welsh law, and enhancing the civil justice system through digitalisation. The sector contributed 42.6 billion GBP to UK GVA in 2024 with the UK being the largest Legal Services market in Europe.
priorities.evidence_quote: The UK also excels in lawtech, boasting over 350 companies and attracting more than 5.5 billion of investment in 2023. Our flexible Legal Services regulatory environment and 'tech-neutral' approach provide start-ups the space to innovate.
source_documents: Professional and Business Services sector plan

priorities.description: Position UK consulting industry as global leader in emerging advisory services covering climate transition, digital transformation, and business productivity improvement. Support further increases in exports and provide better access to public data sets and government procurement for SME consultancies.
priorities.evidence_quote: Over the past five years the overall size of the consulting sector in terms of GVA has grown from 22.0 billion in 2019 to 26.4 billion in 2024... The UK consulting industry will be a global leader in new and emerging advisory services, covering climate transition and adaptation and digital transformation.
source_documents: Professional and Business Services sector plan

priorities.description: Bring forward a package of changes to Money Laundering Regulations (MLRs) to improve clarity and proportionality while safeguarding against money laundering and terrorist financing. Encourage use of digital identity for MLR verification checks as part of commitment to reduce administrative costs of regulation by 25%.
priorities.evidence_quote: The Government recognises the importance of ensuring the MLRs are clear and proportionate to the risks. Before the end of this year, HM Treasury will therefore bring forward a package of changes to the MLRs aimed at improving their effectiveness.
source_documents: Professional and Business Services sector plan

priorities.priority_name: Office for Professional and Business Services (OPBS)
priorities.description: Develop a proposal for the creation of an Office for Professional and Business Services to oversee implementation of the Sector Plan and develop the programme further. Reform the Professional and Business Services Council (PBSC) with a permanent secretariat and annual State of the Sector reporting.
priorities.evidence_quote: Develop a proposal for the creation of an Office for Professional and Business Services (OPBS), to oversee implementation of the Plan and to develop the programme further. Reform of the PBSC to ensure it can act as a champion for the sector at home and abroad.
source_documents: Professional and Business Services sector plan

priorities.description: Improve PBS SMEs' access to growth finance through British Business Bank's Industrial Strategy Growth Capital initiative (4 billion GBP), explore IP-backed lending for PBS emerging technologies, and target inward investment into digital transformation consultancies and emerging PBS technology providers.
priorities.evidence_quote: The BBB's total financial capacity will increase to 25.6 billion. Its baseline activity each year is set to increase by around two-thirds... At the heart of these reforms is a new 4 billion ISGC initiative, which will include more flexible and customised approaches to support the needs of sectors, including PBS.
source_documents: Professional and Business Services sector plan

priorities.priority_name: PBS Export Growth and Market Access
priorities.description: Boost UK PBS global exports (already second largest exporter globally at 183 billion GBP in 2024) through new Free Trade Agreements, tackling overseas barriers, expanding Recognition of Professional Qualifications (RPQ) arrangements, and delivering overseas marketing campaigns and trade missions targeting US, EU, India, and Australia.
priorities.evidence_quote: The UK is the second-largest exporter of PBS in the world and our PBS exports have grown dramatically from 117 billion in 2019 to 183 billion in 2024... We will continue to tackle overseas barriers for UK PBS by delivering certainty and improving market access.
source_documents: Professional and Business Services sector plan

priorities.description: Build a highly skilled, digitally literate domestic PBS workforce through expansion of the AI Skills Hub, continued funding for Level 7 apprenticeships for young people, introduction of short courses funded through Growth and Skills Levy in digital, AI and engineering. Address skills gaps in digital, climate transition, and cybersecurity.
priorities.evidence_quote: We will expand the AI Skills Hub, launching in the summer of 2025, to include PBS. This will bring together industry stakeholders, training providers, and AI technology partners in an online portal to address AI skills-related barriers within PBS firms.
source_documents: Professional and Business Services sector plan

priorities.priority_name: Professional and Business Services Investment Target
priorities.description: Target to double annual business investment from 35 billion to 65 billion GBP by 2035.
priorities.evidence_quote: Double annual business investment in the sector from GBP 35 billion to GBP 65 billion in 2035.
source_documents: Technical Annex to the UK Industrial Strategy

priorities.priority_name: Professional and Business Services Tech Adoption
priorities.description: Increasing tech adoption and AI integration in the PBS sector including new digital fields like LawTech and PropTech.
priorities.evidence_quote: Increase tech adoption and AI integration in the Professional and Business Services sector, including adopting the Made Smarter scheme, as part of a package of £150 million to support the sector.
commitments: £150 million package for PBS sector
Made Smarter expansion to PBS
PBS Hubs in Liverpool, Greater Manchester, West Yorkshire, West Midlands, Edinburgh-Glasgow
Smart Data programme for property sector
source_documents: UK Industrial Strategy - Main Policy Paper (CP 1451)

priorities.description: Develop digital and regulatory sandboxes initially focused on PropTech, work with Centre for Finance, Innovation and Technology (CFIT) to develop 'open property' concept, and implement Smart Data programme for property sector to streamline transactions and boost productivity in real estate.
priorities.evidence_quote: We will initially focus on PropTech, in light of our industry engagement highlighting the sector's readiness for innovation and the significant growth potential it holds. This includes areas where PropTech has the potential to transform the planning, housing, land, and infrastructure markets.
source_documents: Professional and Business Services sector plan

priorities.description: Establish five new PBS Hubs in Liverpool City Region, Greater Manchester, West Yorkshire, West Midlands, and Edinburgh-Glasgow Central Belt. These hubs will be centres of national excellence providing enhanced support and coordination on trade and investment promotion, technology adoption, and skills development, co-created with Mayoral Strategic Authorities and the Scottish Government.
priorities.evidence_quote: We will co-create PBS Hubs in Liverpool City Region, Greater Manchester, West Yorkshire, West Midlands, and Edinburgh-Glasgow Central Belt, by working with the MSAs and the Scottish Government. Each Hub will be tailored to support both national and local PBS priorities.
source_documents: Professional and Business Services sector plan

priorities.description: Enable easier access for SMEs to government procurement through the Procurement Act 2023, which came into force in February 2025. Introduce targets for direct spend with SMEs, exclude suppliers from major contracts if they do not pay contractors on time, and publish key performance indicators for major procurements.
priorities.evidence_quote: The Procurement Act 2023 came into force on 24 February 2025, making it simpler and more efficient for new entrants and smaller firms to bid for public procurement opportunities... government is now going further to ensure public procurement support for our Industrial Strategy priorities.
source_documents: Professional and Business Services sector plan

priorities.description: Establish a Trade Digitalisation Task Force to harness productivity and growth benefits from digitalisation of trade and investment, enabled through the Electronic Trade Documents Act (ETDA). Pursue digital trade partnerships and digital economy agreements with key overseas markets.
priorities.evidence_quote: Working with the PBSC and the sector, we will harness the productivity and growth benefits to PBS firms and their clients from the digitalisation of trade and investment. With representation from across the PBS sector, the Task Force will work with government and regulators to quantify the benefits and barriers to adoption of digital trade instruments.
source_documents: Professional and Business Services sector plan
